review_body:
Blue Buffalo Spa Select is great! Top of the line ingredients, human food grade-- there's a chicken version and a fish version. I'm really careful to keep on top of the literature about pet foods, and so I'm confident that this food meets a high standard. No yucky meat "by-products", meat and meat meals are the top ingredients, in addition to a host of wholesome and varied ingredients and probiotics.

On top of that, this is an incredibly palatable food. My cat LOVES it. In fact, she scarfs it right down, when she typically has just grazed on a piece or two at a time of other premium foods. I have to be careful to use a measuring cup and not overfeed her, 'cause she will seek me out and meow for more!

Blue Buffalo uses a unique process to manufacture "lifebits" which are added to the food. These smaller, darker pieces are cold formed in order to maintain nutrients. I don't believe any other company incorporates this kind of element into cat or dog food.

I came across this cat food at the local Tractor supply (I was there to buy chicken feed!). I'd never heard or read about Blue Buffalo, but I respect what they are doing, and I've changed to Blue Buffalo dog food for my golden retrievers, too.
summary: tasty, human grade ingredients, unique manufacturing process

But then we got a kitten, and she was eating this dry food too because we open feed the dry and combine with small servings of wet food. Eventually the kitten developed diarrhea, and I thought for sure it was the wet food. So I stopped serving them the wet food completely for three days, and the diarrhea actually got worse. So I tried the opposite, just feeding them wet food at intervals and removing the dry food completely (also for three days), and poof! Magically, no more diarrhea. Also, frankly, my overweight adult cat has not been losing any weight on this food. It helped her stop gaining weight initially, but she is still overweight and has stopped seeing any improvement for months. I've also noticed less vomiting from both cats since I stopped feeding them this dry food. So it's no longer having an effect from a weight loss perspective in my adult cat, and my kitten is having some kind of a reaction to it. Also, I noticed that when my cats were eating this food they went through LARGE quantities of water. Multiple bowls each day. Apparently some vets recommend feeding only wet food (difficult when open-feeding) because it is better for kitty hydration. But I suspect that this particular dry food is a bit worse, because I did notice that my cats were going through far more water than they had on other brands of dry food. review_body:
I have to join the bad reviews for this one as it made my cat's digestive problems worse. I used to feed him Taste of the Wild, which I get at a tractor supply shop, but I thought I'd "upgrade" him to better food and chose Blue Buffalo Sensitive Stomach because my cat does have occasional digestive issues.

Blue Buffalo Sensitive Stomach is more expensive than Taste of the Wild, but did not equate a better quality food!

He ate it for one month, and during that time he was fine at first, then began having dandruff and losing fur on his back legs! He seemed to be very itchy! As soon as I noticed the problem, I had a strong feeling it was the food. I spoke with a relative who is a vet, who said to switch the food and bring him in to her office if the problem didn't go away.

I switched him back to Taste of the Wild and his skin problems began clearing up within days.

We've determined he's allergic to grains. The ingredients in this food include grains: rice, oatmeal, barley. Cats are carnivores. Carnivores don't eat grains.

I think that many cats could do fine on this food if they don't have a grain sensitivity, but I understand the bad reviews and have to add my own. I am happy that other people like it, and that they're cats are doing well, but I can't recommend this food to anyone looking to switch to a "good food." This isn't worth the cost.

If your cat has a sensitive stomach, go with something grain free. Even if your cat doesn't have a grain allergy, it's just not something they should be eating (in my opinion). I wish I would have been more thorough and read the ingredients before purchasing.

For grain free: Taste of the Wild is great, or look at Blue Buffalo's "Freedom" line which does not include grain.
summary: Not worth the cost: Cats aren't supposed to eat grain
